text: hey guys it's Elise and welcome back to
my cupcake addiction on today's episode
I'm gonna be showing you how to make DIY
conversation hearts using jello these
are perfect for Valentine's Day they're
so easy to customize and they taste way
better than the originals let's get
started to make your heart you're going
to need some jello or jelly as we call
it in Australia and you can choose your
colors I use some blue some yellow and
some red for the ones you can see made
here but I'm going to be showing you
guys how to make it with the pink
bubblegum today I've got some sprite or
lemonade I've also got some sifted
powdered or confectioner's sugar and I'm
using a red edible marker today but you
can also use straight food dye I've got
a spatula and I've got a couple of
cookie cutters in heart shapes you can
make conversation stars conversation
ponies whatever you like here I've also
got a rolling pin a little cup measure a
bowl for mixing in and I've also got
just a saucepan so you'll need heat for
this recipe otherwise you could just
dissolve the jello using boiling water
rather than the lemonade and there won't
be quite as sweet I've got an electric
mixer you don't need to have this but it
will make your job a lot easier and I've
also got a baking tray just lined with
some baking paper you want to measure
out just a quarter of a cup of your
liquid as I said I'm using the sprite or
the lemonade a quarter of a cup is all
you need here regardless of what your
pack of instructions say I'm putting
that into a saucepan and then I'm adding
the entire packet of my jelly or jello
and these are going to taste like
bubblegum and they're gonna be colored
pink just like bubblegum I'm just gonna
stir that around and I'm gonna bring
that to the boil once it's boiling you
can take it off the heat doesn't have to
boil for long literally just get it
bubbling and get it off the heat once
you're happy all these little jelly
crystals have dissolved you can transfer
it into your bowl but make sure that
you're ready to start adding your
powdered sugar at this point because it
will start to set really quickly that's
a really thick jello we've made you want
to add in your icing sugar your
confectioner sugar about a 1/2 a cup or
a cup at a time
so I'm using the electric mixer because
it just saves so much time and so much
arm power here and you just want to beat
that through it's gonna be really
liquidy to begin with so as we get
towards the second sort of third of that
powdered sugar it's gonna start to get
really thick you don't want to add in
all of your powdered sugar using this
electric mixer and you may not need all
of the quantities that I've listed in
your ingredients down below once it
starts to look like this you can see
here it's getting chunky
stop using your electric mixer or you
are going to kill the motor so just take
it off the electric mixer and then we're
going to pop a lot of icing sugar down
on the bench and coat your hands as well
and you're gonna tip out your kind of
crumbly dough a mix knead that and as
you knead it it's almost gonna start to
feel like a fondant or a modeling
chocolate it gets a really pliable just
like play-doh you want to knead it and
continue adding confectioners sugar into
it until it stops sticking to the bench
so as you knead it into the bench by the
time it stops sticking any of its of
remainders to the bench then you know
it's ready to go sit it aside on the
bench for about 15 minutes and let it
form a bit of a crust which just helps
it dry out and makes it a lot easier to
work with once you can see all those
cracks they kind of look a bit like
elephant skin you just want to knead it
for about 10 or 20 seconds just on the
bench and it shouldn't be sticking at
all at this point you can see there it's
softening just as we need it and it's
really not taking that long sprinkle
down another generous amount of that
icing sugar and then you want to roll
your door out now as you roll it you'll
notice that I keep it moving so I roll
once and then I pick it up and I turn it
around this is just stop it from
sticking to the bench the thinner you
roll these the quicker they'll dry the
thicker you make them the longer they'll
take so just cut out some of your love
heart shapes and then place them onto
your baking paper line to tray now
they're gonna take at least 48 hours at
room temperature in a nice dry
environment to completely dry but I
decided to speed up the process by
placing them in my oven on its lowest
possible temperature of 50 degrees for
an hour on each side so give them an
hour on one side and then flip them to
the other side if they're not flipping
easily give them a little bit longer so
don't break them as you flip
them they should be quite ready to flip
kind of like a done pancake once they're
completely dry so they break when you
break one and they don't Bend then you
can start adding a text if you add it
before this it's going to run you can
use whatever you like to add this text
food color and cookie icing but the
edible markers really are the easiest
and neatest way to get your little
messages on there I hope you guys have
enjoyed this video i hope that you'll
recreate some amazing ideas with some
really cute little messages for your
Valentine this year if you think this is
a cool idea I'd love it if you'd share
the video give it a thumbs up or let me
know down below as always guys thanks
very much for tuning in to my cupcake
addiction
